head.title: Bioinspired Synthesis of Melaninlike Nanoparticles for Highly N-Doped Carbons Utilized as Enhanced CO2 Adsorbents and Efficient Oxygen Reduction Catalysts | ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

meta.content: Bioinspired Synthesis of Melaninlike Nanoparticles for Highly N-Doped Carbons Utilized as Enhanced CO2 Adsorbents and Efficient Oxygen Reduction Catalysts

Highly N-doped nanoporous carbons have been of great interest as a high uptake CO2 adsorbent and as an efficient metal-free oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalyst. Therefore, it is essential to produce porosity-tunable and highly N-doped carbons through cost-effective means. Herein, we introduce the bioinspired synthesis of a monodisperse and N-enriched melaninlike polymer (MP) resembling the sepia biopolymer (SP) from oceanic cuttlefish. These polymers were subsequently utilized for highly N-doped synthetic carbon (MC) and biomass carbon (SC) spheres. An adequate CO2 activation process fine-tunes the ultramicroporosity (<1 nm) of N-doped MC and SC spheres, those with maximum ultramicroporosities of which show remarkable CO2 adsorption capacities. In addition, N-doped MC and SC with ultrahigh surface areas of 2677 and 2506 m2/g, respectively, showed excellent ORR activities with a favored four electron reduction pathway, long-term durability, and better methanol tolerance, comparable to a commercial Pt-based catalyst.

div.p:
Highly N-doped nanoporous carbons have been of great interest as a high uptake CO
2
adsorbent and as an efficient metal-free oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalyst. Therefore, it is essential to produce porosity-tunable and highly N-doped carbons through cost-effective means. Herein, we introduce the bioinspired synthesis of a monodisperse and N-enriched melaninlike polymer (MP) resembling the
sepia
biopolymer (SP) from oceanic cuttlefish. These polymers were subsequently utilized for highly N-doped synthetic carbon (MC) and biomass carbon (SC) spheres. An adequate CO
2
activation process fine-tunes the ultramicroporosity (<1 nm) of N-doped MC and SC spheres, those with maximum ultramicroporosities of which show remarkable CO
2
adsorption capacities. In addition, N-doped MC and SC with ultrahigh surface areas of 2677 and 2506 m
2
/g, respectively, showed excellent ORR activities with a favored four electron reduction pathway, long-term durability, and better methanol tolerance, comparable to a commercial Pt-based catalyst.

span.p:
Melaninlike polymer and sepia biopolymer are utilized to synthesize highly N-doped nanoporous carbons for excellent CO
2
adsorbents and efficient metal-free oxygen reduction reaction catalysts.

div.div:
Highly N-doped nanoporous carbons have recently made a significant impact on the research areas of CO
2
capture
(1-6)
and metal-free ORR catalysts
(7-12)
The ability of N-doped nanoporous carbons to function within such applications is attributed to the excellent textural features of carbonaceous materials, such as finely tunable pore size distribution (PSD) and high specific surface area (SSA), as well as electronic characteristics arising from the Ï conjugated graphitic system associated with electron-rich N atoms incorporated in the framework.
(13, 14)

The CO
2
capture ability of N-doped nanoporous carbons has been highlighted because a highly enhanced CO
2
capacity is expected from the chemisorption interactions of the acidic nature of CO
2
with electron-rich N sites incorporated within the carbon framework, and the simultaneous maximum development of ultramicropores (<1 nm).
(1, 2)
The quadrupole moment of CO
2
is readily polarized by the dipole moment derived from the N sites of carbon, which renders increased isosteric heats of adsorption (
Q
st
) of CO
2
on the N-doped carbon.
(1, 2)
In addition, the development of ultramicropores (<1 nm) has proven to be a key factor for enhanced CO
2
uptake and can be mediated through the fine-tuning of PSD through various activation methods, among which a hot CO
2
treatment (CO
2
(g) + C(s) â 2CO(g)) for creating ultramicropores is of great interest because it allows the fine-tuning PSD and easy control of experimental conditions.
(1, 2, 15, 16)

On the other hand, highly N-doped carbons have also been investigated as an alternative catalyst for the ORR of fuel cell systems instead of precious Pt-based catalysts owing to low cost, long-term durability, and tolerance toward methanol.
(17-19)
N-Doped carbons have shown outstanding ORR activities arising from the N-doping effect, which induces a perturbation of the electroneutrality of Ï-conjugated graphitic systems, resulting in partial positive-charged carbon sites favorable for adsorption of O
2
and subsequent reduction.
(20-26)
In general, N species located at the edge sites of graphene sheets such as pyridinic, pyrrolic,
(22-24, 27, 28)
and valley graphitic (VG)
(24, 29)
nitrogen show the high catalytic activity of ORR. In addition, it is important to develop microporosity and mesoporosity of N-doped carbons, those of which facilitate the easy approach of reactants to catalytic sites and mass-transport properties, respectively.

Considering the factors demanded for the success of both applications of N-doped carbons, the ability to fine-tune the PSD of micropores and SSA as well as produce a large amount of the required N species should be accomplished simultaneously. In addition, sustainable, cost-effective, and massively producible ways for producing N-doped carbons are necessary. Therefore, utilization of abundant resources such as biomass as a precursor for highly N-doped carbons could be a promising way to accomplish this.

On the other hands, melanin is a well-known biopolymer that is broadly distributed in most living organisms, which has shown characteristic features such as protection of human and animal skin from UV light, free radical quenching, metal ion chelation, antibiotic, thermoregulation, and so on.
(30-37)
Because of such interesting features of melanin biopolymer, biomimetic synthesis of melaninlike polymer (MP) has recently been attempted via a simple chemical oxidation of dopamine biomolecule.
(32-37)
MP can readily be polymerized into monodisperse and nitrogen containing submicrometer spheres, which then are easily converted to highly N-doped carbons.
(32)
Ai et al. synthesized monodisperse MPs using dopamine in the waterâethanol mixture under basic conditions, which were subsequently carbonized. Highly N-doped carbon with high surface area of 2006 m
2
g
â1
presented efficient ORR activity with onset potential of â0.1 V (vs Ag/AgCl).
(32)
Therefore, melanin biomass and biomimetic MP could be good precursors for highly N-doped carbons that potentially present enhanced CO
2
uptake and efficient ORR activity.

Herein, we report the use of biomass and a biomimetic polymer as precursors for highly N-doped nanoporous carbons that can present highly enhanced CO
2
adsorption capacity and serve as an efficient metal-free catalyst for ORR. As a screen for the feasibility of biomass for N-doped carbons, the bioinspired synthesis of size-tunable and monodisperse melaninlike polymer (MP) was achieved; it was confirmed that the chemical structure of MP resembled biomass melanin, such as
sepia
from cuttlefish. Then, MP and
sepia
biomass biopolymer (SP) were used for MP derived carbon (MC) and
sepia
derived N-doped carbon (SC), which were subsequently activated by the hot CO
2
treatment for fine-tuning PSD (especially the micropores) and developing high SSA. The CO
2
activated MC and SC showed an SSA as high as 2677 and 2506 m
2
g
â1
, respectively, and high N-content of up to 12 wt %. As a CO
2
adsorbent, the most optimized MC and SC showed outstanding CO
2
adsorption capacities of 7.83 and 7.27 mmol g
â1
at 273 K at 1 bar, respectively, which are comparable to those of the best carbonaceous CO
2
adsorbents reported so far. In addition, the most activated MC and SC present outstanding ORR activities with a favored four-electron reduction pathway, long-term durability, and better methanol tolerance, comparable to a commercial Pt-based catalyst.

Dopamine hydrochloride (Sigma-Aldrich), ammonia solution (28%, Daejung), Nafion resin solution (5 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich), 2-propanol (Sigma-Aldrich), and ethanol (99.9%, Samchun Chemical) were used without purification. High purity gases were used for all adsorption experiments. (N
2
99.999%, CO
2
99.999%, Ar 99.9%, O
2
99.9%)

The detailed synthesis parameters are shown in
Table S1
. A 1.08 g portion of dopamine hydrochloride was dissolved in the solution of water (280 mL) and ethanol (80 mL) mixture. Under vigorous stirring, 1 mL of aqueous ammonia solution (28% NH
3
(aq)) was added to a dopamine hydrochloride solution at room temperature. After stirring for 12 h, MP was retrieved by centrifugation and washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times. For the carbonization process, MP was heated from ambient temperature to various temperatures (380, 600, and 800 Â°C) with a heating rate of 4.3 Â°C/min and stayed for 3 h under an N
2
atmosphere.

Cuttlefish inks were obtained by dissection of Korean cuttlefish.
Sepia
was extracted by syringe from the cuttlefish and obtained by centrifugation (8000 rpm). After several washing processes of centrifugation in water, a dispersed solution of clean sepia polymer was obtained. For the carbonization process, SP was heated from ambient temperature to 600 Â°C with a heating rate of 4.3 Â°C/min and stayed for 3 h under N
2
atmosphere. After carbonization process, SC was treated with 2 M HCl solution with 48 h to eliminate impurities.

div.h3:
CO
2
Activation of MC and SC Samples
div.div:
Carbon dioxide activation was performed using 200 mg of MC and SC. Carbon samples were placed in an alumina boat in a quartz tube in the isothermal zone of a tubular furnace that was purged with a flow of nitrogen. The samples were heated to an elevated temperature of 900 Â°C with a heating rate (30 Â°C/min) under nitrogen gas condition, and the gas was changed to carbon dioxide (1000 cm
3
/min) for various times (65 and 130 min for MC, and 50 and 120 min for SC). After the programmed activation processes, the gas flux was changed to nitrogen during the cooling down process. Activated carbon samples were denoted as MC_CX and SC_CX, where X is the CO
2
activation time.

Low temperature nitrogen adsorptionâdesorption isotherms were measured at â196 Â°C on an adsorption volumetric analyzer BEL MAX manufactured by BEL, Inc. (Japan). All samples were degassed at 200 Â°C for 12 h under static vacuum before adsorption measurements. Specific surface area was determined by the BrunnauerâEmmetâTeller (BET) method from nitrogen adsorption isotherms in the relative pressure range of 0.05â0.20. Pore size distributions (PSD) and accumulated pore volume of MC and SC series spheres were calculated from adsorption branches of nitrogen sorption isotherms using the NLDFT (nonlocal density functional theory) method for slitlike pores available in the BEL Master software from BEL Inc. The volume of pores below 2, 1, and 0.7 nm were calculated on the basis of accumulated pore volume. The isosteric heat of adsorption (
Q
st
) was calculated using the ClausiusâClapeyron equation. Surface functional groups of the polymer samples were determined by recording FTIR spectra on a Varian Corporation (USA) Varian Scimitar 1000 FT-IR. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained with a HITACHI S-4800 microscope with an accelerating voltage of 15.0 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were measured using a PHI Versa Probe system with a 100-W ALK Alpha X-ray source. Elemental analyses (EA) were obtained using FLASH EA1112. TEM images were recorded on a transmission electron microscope (JEM-2100F). UVâvis spectrometer data was recorded by Optizen 2120UV (MECASYS Inc.). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was obtained using SDT Q600 device (TA Instruments Inc.). X-ray diffraction (XRD) results were obtained on a Rigaku, D/MAX-2500/PC equipped with Cu KÎ± radiation (Î» = 1.5406 Ã ). The
13
C spectrum for the MP was acquired on the 9.4 T spectrometer with a 4 mm zirconia rotor as sample holder spinning at CP/MAS rate Î½
MAS
= 14 kHz. The amounts of impurities in the Sepia polymer were determined by measuring solution concentration using a SPECTRO ARCROS (ARCOROS Inc.) inductively coupled plasma (ICP) atomic emission spectrometer.

A 10 mg portion of carbon samples was mixed with deionized water, Nafion resin solution (5 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich), and 2-propanol (Sigma-Aldrich) via ultrasonication. Catalyst ink was deposited on a glassy carbon electrode with the loading of 0.5 mg/cm
2
. To compare the ORR activity with Pt, commercial 20 wt % Pt/C catalyst (Johnson Mattey) was used as reference catalyst with loading of 40 Î¼g
Pt
/cm
2
. All the electrochemical measurements in this study were carried out at 293 K using a potentiostat (Autolab) in a conventional three electrode cell with Pt wire counter and saturated Ag/AgCl reference electrode. All the potentials reported in this study are relative to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), calibrated by the hydrogen oxidation and evolution reaction potential. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed in the potential range of 0.05â1.10 V (vs RHE) with a scan rate of 50 mV/s. Rotating disk electrode (RDE) and rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) measurements were conducted in O
2
-saturated 0.1 M KOH at 1600 rpm with scan rate of 5 mV/s. During RRDE measurement, the ring potential was set to 1.45 V vs RHE. The nonfaradaic current term was calibrated by subtracting the CV current measured in Ar-saturated solution at the same sweep rate. The apparent electron transfer number and the kinetic current density were estimated by following KouteckyâLevich equation with using the RDE data at 600, 900, 1200, 1600, and 2000 rpm.
(1)
(2)
Here,
i
,
i

, and
i
K
are the measured, diffusion limiting and kinetic current density, respectively. Ï is the rotating speed of electrode,
F
is the Faraday constant (98485 C/mol).
C
0
is the saturated O
2
concentration in bulk solution (1.21 Ã 10
â6
mol/cm
3
),
D
O
2
is the diffusion coefficient of O
2
(1.86 Ã 10
â5
cm
2
/s), and Ï is the kinetic viscosity of electrolyte (0.01 cm
2
/s). The H
2

(3)
Where
i
d
and
i
r
refer to disk current and ring current, respectively, and
N
is the collection efficiency (
N
= 0.37). The methanol tolerance test was conducted with chronoamperometry at a constant voltage of 0.7 V vs RHE with rotating at 1600 rpm. Methanol was added to electrolyte at 400 s until the final molar concentration of methanol reached to 1 M. In each case, the measured currents were normalized to the initial current. The accelerated durability test (ADT) was conducted based on DOE protocol: 10â¯000 times potential cycling between 0.6 and 1.0 V vs RHE at sweep rate of 50 mV/s in Ar-saturated conditions.

The synthetic scheme of highly N-doped nanoporous carbons is depicted in
Figure 1
a. In an attempt to utilize a biomass precursor for N-doped carbons, the bioinspired synthesis of MP was first carried out. Size-tunable and monodisperse MP spheres were synthesized by the modified StÃ¶ber method under a waterâethanol mixture using ammonia catalyst; polymerization of dopamine precursor was carried out under various synthesis conditions (detail synthesis parameters and SEM images for MP spheres shown in the
Table S1
and
Figure S1
). It has been widely accepted that MP can be synthesized by the spontaneous oxidation of dopamine precursors via intra- and intermolecular cross-linking reactions under basic conditions with the presence of O
2
(37)
(
Figure S2
). Among various synthesis conditions, the size of MP is readily tuned by adjusting precursor amounts under the specific condition, of which the size gradually increased from 141 Â± 42 to 390 Â± 22 nm, indicating that spherical and monodisperse MP can be successfully synthesized (
Figures 1
b, c and
Table S1
). It is noted that size-controllable and spherical MP has recently been reported in the numerous papers.
(32-37)
In addition, SP is readily obtained from cuttlefish, and its spherical morphology with a size of 132 Â± 13 nm was identified by SEM measurement (
Figure 1
d).

div.p:
Figure 1. Synthetic scheme and chemical structures of carbon frameworks of the CO
2
activated MC and SC spheres (a). SEM images of the MP (141 Â± 42 nm) (b), MP (390 Â± 22 nm) (c), and SP (132 Â± 13 nm) (d). UVâvis spectrum (e), FT-IR (f), and
13
C ssNMR spectrum of MP (g).

div.div:
The chemical structure of MP (390 Â± 22 nm) was carefully characterized using UVâvis spectrometry, FT-IR, and
13
C solid state NMR (ssNMR). According to the UVâvis spectrum, a broad band UVâvis absorption spectrum of 200â800 nm for MP was observed, which was also observed from the SP (
Figure 1
e). The broad band spectrum of 200â800 nm is a well-known optical characteristic of natural melanin association with human skin protection from UV.
(37)
In addition, SP and MP were characterized by FT-IR. There are several discrepancies that could be attributed to the inherent chemical functionality change of natural melanin during sampling, but both spectra are very similar to each other (
Figure 1
f). The high-resolution
13
C ssNMR spectrum for MP was obtained (
Figure 1
g). The peaks were assigned to quinoid carbonyl peaks (163 ppm), diphenolic phenoxy (142 ppm), aromatic units (115 ppm), indole and pyrrole structure peaks (105 ppm), side-chain C atoms of noncyclized dopa (78 ppm, 39 ppm), and C
2
of dihyroindole units (25 ppm), in accordance with data from previously reported synthetic melanin using dopamine oxidation
(37-42)
(detailed FT-IR and
13
C SSNMR assignments are listed in
Table S2
). The various characterization results in terms of the morphological and chemical features for MP and SP are adequate to suggest that the bioinspired synthesis of MP resembling natural melanin (SP) was successfully accomplished.

MP (390 Â± 22 nm) and SP (132 Â± 13 nm) were used to prepare MP derived and SP derived N-doped carbons (MC and SC), respectively (
Figure 1
c, d). After various carbonization temperatures (380â800 Â°C) were used to monitor the N contents of as-prepared MCs (
Table S3
), it was concluded that MC carbonized at 600 Â°C presented the highest nitrogen content of 12.2 wt %. Thus, MC obtained at 600 Â°C was only considered for the following discussion and SC was also carbonized at 600 Â°C for consistency, of which the nitrogen content was 8.6 wt %.

The size of MC was reduced to 160 Â± 18 nm, probably due to a radial shrinkage during carbonization, which was also observed for SC of 105 Â± 24 nm (
Figure 2
a and c). It was noted that natural SP possesses various minerals (eg., Mg, K, and Na) as determined by ICP, of which the content was around 8.8 wt % as determined by TGA; thus, a removal process of mineral oxides using an acid treatment after carbonization was accomplished, which was confirmed by XRD (
Figure S4
).

div.p: Figure 2. SEM images of MC (a), MC_C130 (b, 110 Â± 21 nm), SC (c), SC_C120 (d, 75 Â± 13 nm) and TEM images of MC (e), MC_C130 (f), SC (g), and SC_C120 (h).

div.div:
The as-prepared MC and SC were activated by hot CO
2
treatment at 900 Â°C, denoted as MC and SC_CX, where X stands for the activation time. The SSAs determined by the BET method were 478, 1659, and 2677 m
2
/g for MC and MC_C65 and 130, respectively; similar tends were also observed for SC and SC_C50 and 120 for 488, 1574, and 2506 m
2
/g, respectively (
Table 1
and
Figure 3
a, b). Such an effective activation process was also identified, by which the size shrinkage for CO
2
activated MC and SC was observed through SEM investigation (
Figures 2
b, d and
S3a, b
), and more porosity development for more activated MC and SC samples was also observed through TEM measurements (
Figures 2
eâh and
Figure S3 c, d
). In addition, the sharp increase of ultramicropore (<1 nm) centered around 0.7 nm, as determined by the NLDFT method for both MC and SC series (
Figure 3
c, d), strongly suggested that the fine-tuning PSD was successfully achieved by hot CO
2
treatment, which should be significantly related to the CO
2
adsorption capacity. It is noted that there was a broad PSD for SC probably due to the removal of mineral oxides (
Figure 3
d). As the CO
2
activation time increased, micropores and mesopores up to around 5 nm also developed, which could render the enhanced mass-transfer properties when used as ORR catalysts (
Figures 3
c, d).

div.p:
Figure 3. N
2
sorption isotherms of MC and SC samples (a and b). The PSD of MC and SC samples (c and d). The percentage changes of N species of MC and SC samples along CO
2
-activation treatments (e and f).

div.div:
Table 1. Textural Properties, CO
2
Uptake Capacities with the
Q
st
Values, and N Contents for the MC and SC Samples

tr.th:
CO
2
adsorbed [mmol/g] (273 K/298 K) at 1Â bar

div.p: Determined by the NLDFT model.
The BET and NLDFT method is used for obtaining micro- and mesopore surface areas.

div.div:
The N contents for the MC and SC series decreased along with CO
2
activation times (12.2, 5.6, and 3.0 wt % for MC and MC_C65 and 130, respectively, and 8.1, 4.6, and 2.2 wt % for SC and SC_C50 and 120, respectively), which is probably due to the relatively weak chemical stability of nitrogen species under the hot CO
2
treatment conditions
(2, 5)
(
Table 1
).

According to the XPS spectra (
Figure S5
), specific nitrogen species such as pyridinic (398.1â398.4 eV), pyrrolic (400.0â400.5 eV), center graphitic (CG, 401.3â401.5 eV), valley graphitic (VG, 402.4â403 eV), and
n
-oxide (405.0â406.5 eV) can be assigned.
(1, 2, 14-16)
Basic pyrrolic and pyridinc nitrogens were major species even after most activated samples (see
Figures 3
e, f and
S5
), which are known to contain beneficial moieties for CO
2
adsorption as well as active catalytic sites for ORR.
(1, 2, 14-16)
Furthermore, it is plausible that increased porosity by activation causes more development of edge sites on graphene sheets; especially, pyridinic and VG nitrogen species are predominantly developed upon prolonged CO
2
activation (
Figure 3
e, f).

CO
2
adsorption isotherms for the MC and SC series were measured at 273 and 298 K at 1 bar (
Figure 4
and
Figure S6a, b
). The CO
2
adsorption capacities measured at 273 K for the MC series (MC and MC_C65 and 130) were 5.5, 7.83, and 6.5 mmol/g, respectively (
Figure 4
a). Similar CO
2
uptake trends for the SC series upon CO
2
activation times were also observed, those of which were 4.95, 7.27, 6.0 mmol/g for the SC and SC_C50 and 120, respectively (
Figure 4
b). This was attributed to the chemical similarity for both MP and SP, to which the same carbonization and activation processes were applied. It is noteworthy that the CO
2
uptake capacities of 7.83 and 7.27 mmol/g for MC_C65 and SC_C50, respectively, are comparable to those of the best carbonaceous CO
2
adsorbents reported so far (
Table S4
). The similar CO
2
adsorption trends for the MC and SC series measured at 298 K are also identified (
Table 1
and
Figure S6a, b
).

div.p:
Figure 4. CO
2
sorption isotherms of (a) MC and (b) SC samples at 273 K.

div.div:
In order to verify the enhanced CO
2
uptake capacities for MC_C65 and SC_C50, structureâproperty relations of the MC and SC series were elucidated in terms of the development of ultramicropores via CO
2
activation and incorporation of N sites. First, it was found that the correlation of CO
2
uptake capacities for both the MC and SC series was strongly related to the amount of accumulated ultramicropore (0.7 and 1 nm) volumes determined by the NLDFT method (
Figure 5
a, b and
Table 1
), indicating the importance of the development of ultramicropores for enhanced CO
2
uptake.
(1, 2, 14-16)

div.p:
Figure 5. Distribution of accumulated ultramicropore volumes (0.7, 1, and 2 nm) of (a) MC and (b) SC samples along with CO
2
adsorption capacities. (c) Relationship plot of CO
2
adsorption capacities with respect to accumulated ultramicropore volume of 1 nm of MC and SC samples, and RFC samples (data retrieved from ref
16
).

div.div:
Basic moieties derived from N sites within a carbon framework facilitate the chemisorption ability of N-doped carbons toward Lewis acidic CO
2
molecules, which eventually imparts increased
Q
st
(see
Figure S6c
and
Table 1
). In order to identify the N-doping effect for CO
2
adsorption, the CO
2
adsorption capacity was compared between a series of carbon samples that showed a linear correlation of CO
2
uptake with respect to accumulated ultramicropore volume.

Recently, our group reported a series of carbon samples (RFC_CX stands for resorcinolâformaldehyde carbon with CO
2
activation of X time) that presented an almost perfect correlation (
R
2
= 0.99) between CO
2
uptake capacities and accumulated ultramicropore volumes up to 1 nm
16
. When the CO
2
uptake capacities of MC and SC samples are plotted in the same graph, all of them are located above the correlation line of the RFC series (
Figure 5
c). Largely enhanced CO
2
uptakes of MC and SC series compared to RFC series having very low N-contents can be ascribed to the chemisorption interaction of the acidic CO
2
with basic N sites incorporated within MC and SC frameworks.

In contrast, the ORR activities of MC and SC samples were initially investigated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) in a 0.1 M KOH electrolyte (
Figure S7
). The CV curves measured in an O
2
-saturated electrolyte (solid line) show well-defined cathodic peaks in all the samples, while no cathodic peaks were measured in the N
2
-saturated electrolyte (dotted line). In both samples of catalysts, the peak potentials were moved to the positive direction along with prolonged CO
2
activation times, suggesting that the ORR activities were enhanced with the development of SSA.

Further investigation of the ORR kinetics was carried out with a rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurement in O
2
saturated 0.1 M KOH (
Figures 6
a and b). In both the MC and SC samples, the current densities at 0.1 V vs RHE increased along with prolonged CO
2
activation times (2.89, 4.42, and 4.96 mA/cm
2
for MC and MC_C65 and 130, respectively, and 3.08, 4.62, and 5.38 mA/cm
2
for SC and SC_C50 and 120, respectively). Furthermore, the onset potentials (
E
0
), which are defined as the potential at a cathodic reduction current density of 0.1 mA/cm
2
, were more positive values (0.77, 0.85, 0.9 V for MC and MC_C65 and 130, respectively, and 0.77, 0.86, and 0.89 V for SC and SC_C50 and 120, respectively) for both MC and SC samples (
Figure 6
a and b).

The ORR kinetics of samples was further investigated with variations of rotating rates for disk electrodes (from 600 to 2000 rpm).
(43)
As shown in
Figure S8
, the current density increases with an increase of the rotating speed due to the shorted O
2
diffusion length. The corresponding KouteckyâLevich plots at 0.6 V vs RHE (insets in
Figure S8
) exhibit good linearity, indicating the first-order reaction kinetics with respect to the concentration of dissolved O
2
.
(44)
The electron transfer numbers (
n
) per O
2
molecule calculated from the KL plots indicate that catalysts with higher SSA follow the more favorable four electron pathway (
Figures 6
c and
S9
). The kinetic limiting current densities (
j
k
) at 0.6 V RHE were also derived from the KL plots (insets in
Figure S8
). The
j
k
values of the most activated MC_C130 (48.24 mA/cm
2
) and SC_C120 (48.08 mA/cm
2
) were markedly higher than those of less activated samples, confirming that the faster kinetics for ORR strongly depended on pore development (
Figure 6
c).

Such outstanding ORR activities for the most activated samples should be attributed to the N-doping effect, strongly related with more exposed edge N species through pore development. According to the XPS analysis, the amount of edge N species of pyridinic and VG nitrogen increased; especially, the amount of VG nitrogen sharply increased along with prolonged activation times (
Figures 3
e, f and
6
c). N species located at edge sites of graphene sheets such as pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen have shown high catalytic activity
(22, 23, 27, 28)
and recently, the ORR activity from VG nitrogen has been also identified by both experimental studies and theoretical calculations.
(25)

The rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) measurement was performed to further confirm the ORR pathway by detecting the amount of intermediate peroxide during the ORR process.
(44)
The average H
2
O
2
yielded a decrease along with an increase of the degree of activation, with
n
values approaching four (
Figure S9
). These results are in accordance with the RDE measurements, indicating an improved catalytic efficiency with the development of the pore structure.

The above results indicate that the ORR activity of our samples was closely related with SSA that contained both micropores and mesopores. The most activated samples possessed the largest SSA with highest micropore density, which serves to enlarge accessibility to the catalytic sites (
Figure 6
d and
Table 1
).
(45, 46)
In addition, the development of mesopores with further activation effectively accelerates the mass-transport properties.
(47, 48)
Therefore, combining this with the high quality of the edge located N species, the most activated samples exhibit superior ORR activities compared to the less- and not-activated ones. To verify the robustness of ORR catalysts, the methanol tolerance and long-term stability of the MC_C130 and SC_C120 samples were examined. In the methanol tolerance test, a substantial oxidation current was observed in the Pt/C catalyst; however, no response current was detected for MC_C130 and SC_C120, indicating their inertness to methanol (
Figure 6
e). The durability of MC_C130 and SC_C120 was also confirmed by a negligible performance decay after 10â¯000 potential cycles (
Figure S10
).

In summary, the bioinspired synthesis of monodisperse and size-tunable MP resembling biomass SP in terms of the chemical and morphological features was successfully achieved, and both were utilized for highly N-doped nanoporous carbons. An adequate activation process enabled us to maximize the ultramicropore volume of MC and SC samples bearing electron-rich N sites, those of which presented superb CO
2
adsorption capacities among carbonaceous materials. In addition, highly activated MC and SC samples yielded outstanding ORR activities comparable to a commercial Pt-based catalyst; this was ascribed to the highly developed accessible micro- and mesopores, and the highly exposed edge N species. Therefore, the successful synthesis and application of biomimetic materials could lead to a way to utilize abundant biomass wastes to valuable resources which are sustainable, cost-effective, and massively producible.

Nitrogen Enriched Porous Carbon Spheres: Attractive Materials for Supercapacitor Electrodes and CO2 Adsorption
Wickramaratne, Nilantha P.; Xu, Jiantie; Wang, Min; Zhu, Lin; Dai, Liming; Jaroniec, Mietek

Nitrogen-contg. polymer and carbon spheres were obtained by the sol-gel method. In particular, the nitrogen-rich carbon spheres were prepd. by 1-pot hydrothermal synthesis in the presence of resorcinol/formaldehyde as carbon precursors and ethylenediamine (EDA) as both a base catalyst and nitrogen precursor, followed by carbonization in nitrogen and activation with CO2. The introduction of EDA to the sol-gel system resulted in structurally bonded nitrogen-contg. carbon spheres. The nitrogen doping level and the particle size can be tuned by varying the EDA amt. in the reaction mixt. The max. nitrogen doping level of 7.2% in carbon spheres could be achieved without sacrificing the spherical morphol. The diam. of these carbon spheres (CS) can be tuned in the rage of 50-1200 nm by varying the EDA amt. N2 adsorption anal. showed that the aforementioned activated carbon spheres exhibited high surface area reaching up to 1224 m2/g. Ultra high CO2 adsorption capacities, 4.1 and 6.2 mmol/g, corresponding to an equil. pressure of 1 bar, were measured on nitrogen-contg. activated carbon spheres at 25 and 0Â°, resp. Electrochem. measurements performed on these carbon spheres for double layer capacitors showed very high capacitance up to â¼388 F/g at 1.0 A/g, outstanding rate capability (60% capacitance retention at 100 A/g), and unprecedented cycling stability (â¼98% capacitance retention even after 8000 cycles) in 1 M H2SO4 electrolyte soln.

Exceptional gas adsorption properties by nitrogen-doped porous carbons derived from benzimidazole-linked polymers
Ashourirad, Babak; Sekizkardes, Ali Kemal; Altarawneh, Suha; El-Kaderi, Hani M.
Chemistry of Materials

Heteroatom-doped porous carbons are emerging as platforms for use in a wide range of applications including catalysis, energy storage, and gas sepn. or storage, among others. The use of high activation temps. and heteroatom multiple-source precursors remain great challenges, and this study aims to addresses both issues. A series of highly porous N-doped carbon (CPC) materials was successfully synthesized by chem. activation of benzimidazole-linked polymers (BILPs) followed by thermolysis under argon. The high temp. synthesized CPC-700 reaches surface area and pore vol. as high as 3240 m2 g-1 and 1.51 cm3 g-1, resp., while low temp. activated CPC-550 exhibits the highest ultramicropore vol. of 0.35 cm3 g-1. The controlled activation process endows CPCs with diverse textural properties, adjustable nitrogen content (1-8 wt %), and remarkable gas sorption properties. In particular, exceptionally high CO2 uptake capacities of 5.8 mmol g-1 (1.0 bar) and 2.1 mmol g-1 (0.15 bar) at ambient temp. were obtained for materials prepd. at 550 Â°C due to a combination of a high level of N-doping and ultramicroporosity. Furthermore, CPCs prepd. at higher temps. exhibit remarkable total uptake for CO2 (25.7 mmol g-1 at 298 K and 30 bar) and CH4 (20.5 mmol g-1 at 298 K and 65 bar) as a result of higher total micropores and small mesopores vol. Interestingly, the N sites within the imidazole rings of BILPs are intrinsically located in pyrrolic/pyridinic positions typically found in N-doped carbons. Therefore, the chem. and phys. transformation of BILPs into CPCs is thermodynamically favored and saves significant amts. of energy that would otherwise be consumed during carbonization processes.

Highly porous N-doped carbons have been successfully prepd. by using KOH as activating agent and polypyrrole (PPy) as carbon precursor. These materials were investigated as sorbents for CO2 capture. The activation process was carried out under severe (KOH/PPy = 4) or mild (KOH/PPy = 2) activation conditions at different temps. in the 600-800 Â°C range. Mildly activated carbons have two important characteristics: (i) they contain a large no. of nitrogen functional groups (up to 10.1 wt% N) identified as pyridonic-N with a small proportion of pyridinic-N groups, and (ii) they exhibit, in relation to the carbons prepd. with KOH/PPy = 4, narrower micropore sizes. The combination of both of these properties explains the large CO2 adsorption capacities of mildly activated carbon. In particular, a very high CO2 adsorption uptake of 6.2 mmolÂ·g-1 (0 Â°C) was achieved for porous carbons prepd. with KOH/PPy = 2 and 600 Â°C (1700 m2Â·g-1, pore size â 1 nm and 10.1 wt% N). Furthermore, we obsd. that these porous carbons exhibit high CO2 adsorption rates, a good selectivity for CO2-N2 sepn. and it can be easily regenerated.

Significantly Increased CO2 Adsorption Performance of Nanostructured Templated Carbon by Tuning Surface Area and Nitrogen Doping
Wang, Lifeng; Yang, Ralph T.

Carbon dioxide adsorption properties of a series of templated carbon adsorbents with high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface areas (1361-3840 m2/g) and with/without nitrogen doping (6-7 wt % N) were systematically studied. Two linear relationships between CO2 adsorption capacities and surface areas of nitrogen-doped/undoped nanostructured templated carbons were first established. The doped nitrogen was present in the forms of pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrolic/pyridonic nitrogen, quaternary nitrogen, and an oxidized form of nitrogen. The interaction energies with CO2, as approximated by the isosteric heats of adsorption, were increased from 30 kJ/mol on the undoped carbon to 50 kJ/mol on the N-doped carbon as a result of these nitrogen sites. The increased interactions led to an enhancement in CO2 adsorption capacity by a factor of 2, while N2 uptake was not enhanced. The optimized N-doped templated carbon, N-TC-EMC, possessed remarkable CO2 capacity (4 mmol/g at 1 atm and 298 K) and selectivity (CO2/N2 at 1 atm = 14). Postdoping ammonia treatment was found beneficial to CO2 adsorption. CO2 performance of N-doped carbon under wet condition and conditions relevant to flue gas, rates of adsorption, and regeneration requirement, which are important for practical applications, were also investigated. The results showed that N-doped templated carbon exhibited all prerequisite attributes for CO2 capture and storage applications: high CO2 capacity and CO2/N2 selectivity, fast and reversible adsorption, thermal and moisture stabilities, and ease in CO2 desorption.

Nitrogen-Doped Carbon Nanotube Arrays with High Electrocatalytic Activity for Oxygen Reduction
Gong, Kuanping; Du, Feng; Xia, Zhenhai; Durstock, Michael; Dai, Liming

The large-scale practical application of fuel cells will be difficult to realize if the expensive platinum-based electrocatalysts for oxygen redn. reactions (ORRs) cannot be replaced by other efficient, low-cost, and stable electrodes. Here, we report that vertically aligned nitrogen-contg. carbon nanotubes (VA-NCNTs) can act as a metal-free electrode with a much better electrocatalytic activity, long-term operation stability, and tolerance to crossover effect than platinum for oxygen redn. in alk. fuel cells. In air-satd. 0.1 M potassium hydroxide, we obsd. a steady-state output potential of -80 mV and a c.d. of 4.1 milliamps per square centimeter at -0.22 V, compared with -85 mV and 1.1 milliamps per square centimeter at -0.20 V for a platinum-carbon electrode. The incorporation of electron-accepting nitrogen atoms in the conjugated nanotube carbon plane appears to impart a relatively high pos. charge d. on adjacent carbon atoms. This effect, coupled with aligning the NCNTs, provides a four-electron pathway for the ORR on VA-NCNTs with a superb performance.

A review. The aim of this article is to provide a comprehensive review of the topic by summarizing all the important developments in this emerging field of active research on carbon-based metal-free catalysts for Oxygen Redn. Reaction (ORR) and presenting crit. issues, challenges, and perspectives. Through such a crit. and comprehensive review, the understanding of metal-free catalytic materials and the assocd. catalytic processes (e.g., ORR, OER, HER) will significantly increase as will the ability to control and even tailor the characteristics of metal-free catalysts for energy-related electrocatalysis.

Efficient metal-free oxygen reduction in alkaline medium on high-surface-area mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbons made from ionic liquids and nucleobases
Yang, Wen; Fellinger, Tim-Patrick; Antonietti, Markus
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(

Mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbon materials with high surface areas up to 1500 m2 g-1 were conveniently made by the carbonization of nucleobases dissolved in an all-org. ionic liq. (1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium dicyanamide). Using hard templating with silica nanoparticles, this process yields high-surface-area nitrogen-doped carbon materials with nitrogen contents as high as 12 wt %, narrow mesopore size distribution of ca. 12 nm diam., and local graphitic carbon structure. It is demonstrated that the resulting nitrogen-doped carbons show very high catalytic activity, even in the metal-free case in the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) for fuel cells. Specifically, the as-prepd. materials exhibit a low onset voltage for ORR in alk. medium and a high methanol tolerance, compared with those of com. 20 wt % Pt/C catalyst. We regard this as a first step toward an all-sustainable fuel cell, avoiding noble metals.

He, Wenhui; Wang, Ying; Jiang, Chunhuan; Lu, Lehui

Developing non-precious metal electrocatalysts (NPMCs) for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) is of paramount importance for com. implementation of several clean energy techniques (e.g. proton exchange membrane fuel cells). However, limited understanding of the ORR catalytic mechanism of NPMCs greatly hinders the progress in the precise fabrication of NPMCs at the mol. or at. level. Recently, an increasing no. of studies have demonstrated the crucial role of a carbon matrix in exposing, stabilizing, and activating the catalytic sites, thus providing a platform to identify the nature of NPMCs. Herein, the unique structural effects of a carbon matrix in NPMCs are first reviewed to inspire the development of more advanced NPMCs for the ORR.

Recent advancements in Pt and Pt-free catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction
Nie, Yao; Li, Li; Wei, Zidong
Chemical Society Reviews
(
2015
),

(
8
),
2168-2201
CODEN:
CSRVBR
; ISSN:
0306-0012
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Developing highly efficient catalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) is key to the fabrication of com. viable fuel cell devices and metal-air batteries for future energy applications. Herein, we review the most recent advances in the development of Pt-based and Pt-free materials in the field of fuel cell ORR catalysis. This review covers catalyst material selection, design, synthesis, and characterization, as well as the theor. understanding of the catalysis process and mechanisms. The integration of these catalysts into fuel cell operations and the resulting performance/durability are also discussed. Finally, we provide insights into the remaining challenges and directions for future perspectives and research.

Nitrogen-doped graphene: efficient growth, structure, and electronic properties
Usachov D; Vilkov O; Gruneis A; Haberer D; Fedorov A; Adamchuk V K; Preobrajenski A B; Dudin P; Barinov A; Oehzelt M; Laubschat C; Vyalikh D V

(

5401-7
ISSN:

A novel strategy for efficient growth of nitrogen-doped graphene (N-graphene) on a large scale from s-triazine molecules is presented. The growth process has been unveiled in situ using time-dependent photoemission. It has been established that a postannealing of N-graphene after gold intercalation causes a conversion of the N environment from pyridinic to graphitic, allowing to obtain more than 80% of all embedded nitrogen in graphitic form, which is essential for the electron doping in graphene. A band gap, a doping level of 300 meV, and a charge-carrier concentration of â¼8Ã10(12) electrons per cm2, induced by 0.4 atom % of graphitic nitrogen, have been detected by angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, which offers great promise for implementation of this system in next generation electronic devices.

The authors report a controlled synthesis of a novel N-doped hierarchical carbon that exhibits record-high Henry's law CO2/N2 selectivity among physisorptive carbons while having a high CO2 adsorption capacity. Specifically, our synthesis involves the rational design of a modified pyrrole mol. that can co-assemble with the soft Pluronic template via hydrogen bonding and electrostatic interactions to give rise to mesopores followed by carbonization. The low-temp. carbonization and activation processes allow for the development of ultrasmall pores (d < 0.5 nm) and preservation of nitrogen moieties, essential for enhanced CO2 affinity.

Highly Enhanced Gas Sorption Capacities of N-Doped Porous Carbon Spheres by Hot NH3 and CO2 Treatments
Kim, Hee Soo; Kang, Min Seok; Yoo, Won Cheol
Journal of Physical Chemistry C
(
2015

(

JPCCCK

Highly enhanced CO2 and H2 adsorption properties were achieved with a series of phenolic resin-based carbon spheres (resorcinol-formaldehyde carbon (RFC) and phenol-formaldehyde carbon (PFC)) by carbonization of RF and PF polymer (RFP and PFP) spheres synthesized via a sol-gel reaction and subsequent activation with hot CO2 or NH3 treatment. Monodisperse and size-tunable (100-600 nm) RFC and PFC spheres had intrinsic nitrogen contents (ca. 1.5 wt. %), which are attributed to the synthesis conditions that utilized NH3 as a basic catalyst as well as nitrogen precursor. A series of CO2-activated and N-doped RFC and PFC spheres showed almost perfect correlation (R2 = 0.99) between CO2 adsorption capacities and accumulated pore vols. of fine micropores (ultramicropore <1 nm) obtained using the nonlocal d. functional theory (NLDFT) model. Interestingly, NH3 activation served not only as an effective method for heteroatom doping (i.e., nitrogen) into the carbon framework but also as an excellent activation process to fine-tune the surface area and pore size distribution (PSD). Increased nitrogen doping levels up to ca. 2.8 wt. % for NH3-activated RFC spheres showed superior CO2 adsorption capacities of 4.54 (1 bar) and 7.14 mmol g-1 (1 bar) at 298 and 273 K, resp. Compared to CO2-activated RFC spheres with similar ultramicropore vol. presenting CO2 uptakes of 4.41 (1 bar) and 6.86 mmol g-1 (1 bar) at 298 and 273 K, resp., NH3-activated nitrogen-enriched RFC was found to have elevated chemisorption ability. Moreover, prolonged activation of RFC and PFC spheres provided ultrahigh surface areas, one of which reached 4079 m2g-1 with an unprecedented superb H2 uptake capacity of 3.26 wt. % at 77 K (1 bar), representing one of the best H2 storage media among carbonaceous materials and metal-org. frameworks (MOFs).

span.span: The Role of Pre-Defined Microporosity in Catalytic Site Formation for the Oxygen Reduction Reaction in Iron-and Nitrogen-doped Carbon Materials

The role of pre-defined microporosity in catalytic site formation for the oxygen reduction reaction in iron- and nitrogen-doped carbon materials
Kim, Minhyoung; Kim, Hee Soo; Yoo, Sung Jong; Yoo, Won Cheol; Sung, Yung-Eun
Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability
(
2017
),
5
(

4199-4206
CODEN:
JMCAET
; ISSN:
2050-7496
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
The microporous structure of Fe-N-doped carbon (Fe-N-C) catalysts plays a pivotal role in the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) because the catalytically active N-coordinated Fe ion sites are located within accessible micropores (<2 nm). However, the distinct role of carbon support microporosity in the formation of catalytic sites in Fe-N-C catalysts remains unclear. Here, we report the effect of the pre-defined microporosity of the parent carbon support on the catalytic site d. resulting from Fe-N-C catalyst synthesis, and its ultimate effect on ORR activity. The porosity, pore size distribution, and sp. surface area of the carbon supports are initially controlled by using hot CO2 treatment. Then, Fe and N are doped into these supports by precursor impregnation and subsequent pyrolysis. In the synthesized Fe-N-C catalysts, the more developed microporosity in the parent carbon supports facilitates more iron and nitrogen contents, esp. pyridinic nitrogen, and Fe-N-Cs derived from carbon supports with higher microporosities show enhanced ORR activity, strongly suggesting that a high catalytic site d. can be achieved by utilizing carbon supports with well-developed microporosities. The most active Fe-N-C catalyst prepd. using our synthetic route exhibits ORR activity comparable to that of a com. Pt-based catalyst in alk. media.

Nitrogen-doped nanoporous carbon nanosheets derived from plant biomass: an efficient catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction
Chen, Ping; Wang, Li-Kun; Wang, Gan; Gao, Min-Rui; Ge, Jin; Yuan, Wen-Jing; Shen, Yu-Hua; Xie, An-Jian; Yu, Shu-Hong
Energy & Environmental Science

4095-4103
CODEN:
EESNBY

1754-5706
.

Royal Society of Chemistry

Catalysts for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) are crucial in fuel cells. Developing metal-free catalyst with high activity at low-cost and high-vol. prodn. remains a great challenge. Here, we report a novel type of nitrogen-doped nanoporous carbon nanosheets derived from a conveniently available and accessible plant, Typha orientalis. The nanosheets have high surface area (the highest surface area can be 898 m2 g-1), abundant micropores and high content of nitrogen (highest content of 9.1 at.%). The typical product exhibits an unexpected, surprisingly high ORR activity. In alk. media, it exhibits similar catalytic activity but superior tolerance to methanol as compared to com. 20% Pt/C. In acidic media as well, it shows excellent catalytic ability, stability and tolerance to methanol. This low-cost, simple and readily scalable approach provides a straightforward route to synthesize excellent electrocatalysts directly from biomass, which may find broad applications in the fields of supercapacitors, sensors, and gas uptake.

Nitrogen-doped species (NDs) are theor. accepted as a determinant of the catalytic activity of metal-free N-doped carbon (NC) catalysts for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR). However, direct relationships between ND type and ORR activity have been difficult to ext. because the complexity of carbon matrix impairs efforts to expose specific NDs. Herein, we demonstrate the fabrication of a 3D hierarchically porous NC catalyst with micro-, meso-, and macroporosity in one structure, in which sufficient exposure and availability of inner-pore catalytic sites can be achieved due to its super-high surface area (2191 cm2 g-1) and interconnected pore system. More importantly, in-situ formation of graphitic-N species (GNs) on the surface of NC stimulated by KOH activation enables us to exptl. reveal the catalytic nature of GNs for ORR, which is of great significance for the design and development of advanced metal-free NC electrocatalysts.

Nitrogen-doped graphene-rich catalysts derived from heteroatom polymers for oxygen reduction in nonaqueous lithium-O2 battery cathodes
Wu, Gang; Mack, Nathan H.; Gao, Wei; Ma, Shuguo; Zhong, Ruiqin; Han, Jiantao; Baldwin, Jon K.; Zelenay, Piotr
ACS Nano

In this work, we present a synthesis approach for nitrogen-doped graphene-sheet-like nanostructures via the graphitization of a heteroatom polymer, in particular, polyaniline, under the catalysis of a cobalt species using multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) as a supporting template. The graphene-rich composite catalysts (Co-N-MWNTs) exhibit substantially improved activity for oxygen redn. in nonaq. lithium-ion electrolyte as compared to those of currently used carbon blacks and Pt/carbon catalysts, evidenced by both rotating disk electrode and Li-O2 battery expts. The synthesis-structure-activity correlations for the graphene nanostructures were explored by tuning their synthetic chem. (support, nitrogen precursor, heating temp., and transition metal type and content) to investigate how the resulting morphol. and nitrogen-doping functionalities (e.g., pyridinic, pyrrolic, and quaternary) influence the catalyst activity. In particular, an optimal temp. for heat treatment during synthesis is crit. to creating a high-surface-area catalyst with favorable nitrogen doping. The sole Co phase, Co9S8, was present in the catalyst but plays a negligible role in ORR. Nevertheless, the addn. of Co species in the synthesis is indispensable for achieving high activity, due to its effects on the final catalyst morphol. and structure, including surface area, nitrogen doping, and graphene formation. This new route for the prepn. of a nitrogen-doped graphene nanocomposite with carbon nanotube offers synthetic control of morphol. and nitrogen functionality and shows promise for applications in nonaq. oxygen redn. electrocatalysis for Li-O2 battery cathodes.

Exploration of the active center structure of nitrogen-doped graphene-based catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction
Lai, Linfei; Potts, Jeffrey R.; Zhan, Da; Wang, Liang; Poh, Chee Kok; Tang, Chunhua; Gong, Hao; Shen, Zexiang; Lin, Jianyi; Ruoff, Rodney S.
Energy & Environmental Science

We present two different ways to fabricate nitrogen-doped graphene (N-graphene) and demonstrate its use as a metal-free catalyst to study the catalytic active center for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR). N-graphene was produced by annealing of graphene oxide (G-O) under ammonia or by annealing of a N-contg. polymer/reduced graphene oxide (RG-O) composite (polyaniline/RG-O or polypyrrole/RG-O). The effects of the N precursors and annealing temp. on the performance of the catalyst were investigated. The bonding state of the N atom was found to have a significant effect on the selectivity and catalytic activity for ORR. Annealing of G-O with ammonia preferentially formed graphitic N and pyridinic N centers, while annealing of polyaniline/RG-O and polypyrrole/RG-O tended to generate pyridinic and pyrrolic N moieties, resp. Most importantly, the electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst was dependent on the graphitic N content which detd. the limiting c.d., while the pyridinic N content improved the onset potential for ORR. However, the total N content in the graphene-based non-precious metal catalyst does not play an important role in the ORR process.

Nitrogen-doped graphene (N-graphene) was synthesized by CVD of methane in the presence of ammonia. The resultant N-graphene was demonstrated to act as a metal-free electrode with a much better electrocatalytic activity, long-term operation stability, and tolerance to crossover effect than platinum for oxygen redn. via a four-electron pathway in alk. fuel cells. This is the 1st report on the use of graphene and its derivs. as metal-free catalysts for oxygen redn. The important role of N-doping to oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) can be applied to various carbon materials for the development of other metal-free efficient ORR catalysts for fuel cell applications, even new catalytic materials for applications beyond fuel cells.

span.span: On the Mechanism of Enhanced Oxygen Reduction Reaction in Nitrogen-Doped Graphene Nanoribbons

On the mechanism of enhanced oxygen reduction reaction in nitrogen-doped graphene nanoribbons
Kim, Heejin; Lee, Kirak; Woo, Seong Ihl; Jung, Yousung
Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics
(
2011
),
13
(
39
),
17505-17510
CODEN:
PPCPFQ
; ISSN:
1463-9076
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry

Nitrogen (N)-doped carbon materials were shown in recent studies to have promising catalytic activity for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) as a metal-free alternative to platinum, but the underlying mol. mechanism or even the active sites for high catalytic efficiency are still missing or controversial both exptl. and theor. We report here the results of periodic d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. about the ORR at the edge of a graphene nanoribbon (GNR). The edge structure and doped-N near the edge are shown to enhance the oxygen adsorption, the first electron transfer, and also the selectivity toward the four-electron, rather than the two-electron, redn. pathway. We find that the outermost graphitic nitrogen site in particular gives the most desirable characteristics for improved ORR activity, and hence the active site. However, the latter graphitic nitrogen becomes pyridinic-like in the next electron and proton transfer reaction via the ring-opening of a cyclic C-N bond. This inter-conversion between the graphitic and pyridinic sites within a catalytic cycle may reconcile the controversy whether the pyridinic, graphitic, or both nitrogens are active sites.

Intrinsic Relationship between Enhanced Oxygen Reduction Reaction Activity and Nanoscale Work Function of Doped Carbons
Cheon, Jae Yeong; Kim, Jong Hun; Kim, Jae Hyung; Goddeti, Kalyan C.; Park, Jeong Young; Joo, Sang Hoon
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(

Nanostructured carbon materials doped with a variety of heteroatoms have shown promising electrocatalytic activity in the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR). However, understanding of the working principles that underpin the superior ORR activity obsd. with doped nanocarbons is still limited to predictions based on theor. calcns. Herein, it is demonstrated, for the first time, that the enhanced ORR activity in doped nanocarbons can be correlated with the variation in their nanoscale work function. A series of doped ordered mesoporous carbons (OMCs) were prepd. using N, S, and O as dopants; the triple-doped, N,S,O-OMC displayed superior ORR activity and four-electron selectivity compared to the dual-doped (N,O-OMC and S,O-OMC) and the monodoped (O-OMC) OMCs. Significantly, the work functions of these heteroatom-doped OMCs, measured by Kelvin probe force microscopy, display a strong correlation with the activity and reaction kinetics for the ORR. This unprecedented exptl. insight can be used to provide an explanation for the enhanced ORR activity of heteroatom-doped carbon materials.

Active sites of nitrogen-doped carbon materials for oxygen reduction reaction clarified using model catalysts
Guo, Donghui; Shibuya, Riku; Akiba, Chisato; Saji, Shunsuke; Kondo, Takahiro; Nakamura, Junji
Science (Washington, DC, United States)

Nitrogen (N)-doped carbon materials exhibit high electrocatalytic activity for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR), which is essential for several renewable energy systems. However, the ORR active site (or sites) is unclear, which retards further developments of high-performance catalysts. Here, we characterized the ORR active site by using newly designed graphite (highly oriented pyrolytic graphite) model catalysts with well-defined Ï conjugation and well-controlled doping of N species. The ORR active site is created by pyridinic N. Carbon dioxide adsorption expts. indicated that pyridinic N also creates Lewis basic sites. The specific activities per pyridinic N in the HOPG model catalysts are comparable with those of N-doped graphene powder catalysts. Thus, the ORR active sites in N-doped carbon materials are carbon atoms with Lewis basicity next to pyridinic N.

Formation of Active Sites for Oxygen Reduction Reactions by Transformation of Nitrogen Functionalities in Nitrogen-Doped Carbon Nanotubes
Sharifi, Tiva; Hu, Guangzhi; Jia, Xueen; Waagberg, Thomas
ACS Nano

Heat treating N-doped multi-walled C nanotubes contg. up to 6 different types of N functionalities transforms particular N functionalities into other types which are more catalytically active toward O redn. reactions (ORR). In the 1st stage, the unstable pyrrolic functionalities transform into pyridinic functionalities followed by an immediate transition into quaternary center and valley N functionalities. By measuring the electrocatalytic oxidn. redn. current for the different samples, the authors obtain information on the catalytic activity connected to each type of N functionality. Through this, quaternary N valley sites, N-Qvalley, are the most active sites for ORR in N-CNTs. The no. of electrons transferred in the ORR is detd. from ring disk electrode and rotating ring disk electrode measurements. The measurements indicate that the ORR processes proceed by a direct 4-electron pathway for the N-Qvalley and the pyridinic sites while it proceeds by an indirect 2-electron pathway via H2O2 at the N-Qcenter sites. The study gives both insights on the mechanism of ORR on different N functionalities in N-doped C nanostructures and probably to treat samples to maximize the catalytic efficiency of such samples.

Development of biodegradable nanomaterials for drug delivery and cancer theranostics has attracted great attention in recent years. In this work, polydopamine (PDA), a biocompatible polymer, is developed as a promising carrier for loading of both radionuclides and an anticancer drug to realize nuclear-imaging-guided combined radioisotope therapy (RIT) and chemotherapy of cancer in one system. It is found that PDA nanoparticles after modification with poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) can successfully load several different radionuclides such as 99mTc and 131I, as well as an anticancer drug doxorubicin (DOX). While labeling PDA-PEG with 99mTc (99mTc-PDA-PEG) enables in vivo single photon emission computed tomog. imaging, nanoparticles co-loaded with 131I and DOX (131I-PDA-PEG/DOX) can be utilized for combined RIT and chemotherapy, which offers effective cancer treatment efficacy in a remarkably synergistic manner, without rendering significant toxicity to the treated animals. Therefore, this study presents an interesting class of biocompatible nanocarriers, which allow the combination of RIT and chemotherapy, the two extensively applied cancer therapeutic strategies, promising for future clinic translations in cancer treatment.

The timely diagnosis and intervention of bone microdamage are essential for preventing its accumulation and further diminishing the risk of skeletal fracture. Although staining methods have been adopted to better depict the microdamage on bone, their clin. impacts are still limited because they are based on histol. sections which are inherently destructive. Here, highly sensitive and non-invasive in vivo detection of bone crack can be achieved by surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) technique using a carefully chosen polydopamine (PDA)-SERS nanoparticle tag. The bone crack can be specifically labeled by PDA-SERS tags taking advantage of high affinity of PDA towards calcium exposed on the damaged bone, and identified by an intense featured Raman signal both in vitro and in vivo benefiting from the surface-enhanced resonance Raman scattering effect. As a preliminary in vivo application, it is found that PDA-SERS tags present no serious adverse effect in mouse model and hold good biocompatibility. This work may help the development of SERS technique for ultrasensitive in vivo detection of bone crack in clinic.

The authors discuss recent progress towards the establishment of important structure-property-function relationships in eumelanins-key functional bio-macromol. systems responsible for photoprotection and immune response in humans, and implicated in the development of melanoma skin cancer. The authors focus on the link between eumelanin's secondary structure and optical properties such as broad band UV-visible absorption and strong non-radiative relaxation; both key features of the photo-protective function. The authors emphasize the insights gained through a holistic approach combining optical spectroscopy with first principles quantum chem. calcns., and advance the hypothesis that the robust functionality characteristic of eumelanin is related to extreme chem. and structural disorder at the secondary level. This inherent disorder is a low cost natural resource, and it is interesting to speculate as to whether it may play a role in other functional bio-macromol. systems.

This paper presents the high-resoln. 13C and 15N cross-polarization magic angle spinning (CP/MAS) NMR spectra of three natural melanin solids: Sepia officinalis melanin, Sepia officinalis melanin free acid (MFA) and Human hair melanin. The obsd. spectral regions of the solid melanin samples can be assigned to the postulated structural unit of the polymer chain of Sepia MFA derived from soln.-state NMR studies. To assist in the assignment of functional groups in the spectra, the solid-state CP/MAS NMR spectra are compared with high-resoln. 13C and 15N CP/MAS spectra of four model compds., L-dopa, dopamine, 2-methoxycarbonyl-3-ethoxycarbonyl-4-methylpyrrole and Et 5,6-dimethoxyindole-2-carboxylate. To aid further in the assignment of protonated and non-protonated carbon atoms, CP contact time dependence and non-quaternary carbon suppression (NQS) expts. were performed on the melanin samples. The 15N CP/MAS spectra of the melanin samples confirm the presence of indole and pyrrole units in the melanin polymer chain. The NMR peaks obsd. in all of the melanin samples are relatively broad, presumably owing to the presence of free radicals. ESR data shows that all three melanin samples contain localized free radicals (g = 2.007), with the Sepia melanin contg. a 10-fold higher free radical d. than Human hair melanin.

Rational approaches to engineering polydopamine films with tailored properties for surface coating and functionalization are currently challenged by the lack of detailed information about the polymer structure and the mechanism of buildup. Using an integrated chem. and spectroscopic approach enables the demonstration of: (a) a three-component structure of polydopamine, comprising uncyclized (catecholamine) and cyclized (indole) units, as well as novel pyrrolecarboxylic acid moieties; (b) remarkable variations in the relative proportions of the cyclized and uncyclized units with starting dopamine concn.; (c) the occurrence of oligomer components up to the tetramer level; (d) the covalent incorporation of Tris buffer; and (e) the role of dopamine quinone as a crucial control point for directing the buildup pathways and tuning the properties. The importance of the uncyclized amine-contg. units in polydopamine adhesion is also highlighted. The proper selection of substrate concn. and buffer is thus proposed as a practical means of tailoring polydopamine functionality via control of competing pathways downstream of dopamine quinone.

We have successfully prepd. nanoporous Carbon-L and -S materials by using ZIF-7 as a precursor and glucose as an addnl. carbon source. Results indicate that Carbon-L and -S show an appropriate nitrogen content, high surface area, robust pore structure and excellent graphitization degree. The addn. of an environmentally friendly carbon source - glucose - not only improves the graphitization degree of samples, but also plays a key role in removing residual Zn metal and zinc compd. impurities, which makes the resulting materials metal-free in situ nitrogen-doped porous carbons. By further investigating the electrocatalytic performance of these nitrogen-doped porous carbons for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR), we find that Carbon-L, as a metal-free electrocatalyst, shows excellent electrocatalytic activity (the onset and half-wave potentials are 0.86 and 0.70 V vs. RHE, resp.) and nearly four electron selectivity (the electron transfer no. is 3.68 at 0.3 V), which is close to com. 20% Pt/C. Moreover, when methanol was added, the Pt/C catalyst would be poisoned while the Carbon-L and -S would be unaffected. By exploring the current-time chronoamperometric response in 25 000 s, we found that the duration stability of Carbon-L is much better than the com. 20% Pt/C. Thus, both Carbon-L and -S exhibit excellent ability to avoid methanol crossover effects, and long-term operation stability superior to the Pt/C catalyst. This work provides a new strategy for in situ synthesis of N-doped porous carbons as metal-free electrocatalysts for ORR in fuel cells.

The N-MGF catalyst demonstrates lower oxygen evolution reaction (OER) overpotential (324 mV at 10 mA cm-2) than most of the previously reported carbon based materials, non-noble metal oxides and their hybrids, and comparable with noble metal oxides (ruthenium/iridium oxide, RuO2 and IrO2) catalysts. The prepd. N-MGF catalysts also exhibit negligible mass transfer resistance, good durability and bifunctionality in ORR and OER. The significantly improved electrocatalytic performance results from their large surface area, ordered pores, excellent internal diffusion property, and superior intrinsic cond. The materials show great potential for various applications in energy conversion and storage, including fuel cells, electrolyzers and metal-air batteries.

Nitrogen-contg. polymer and carbon spheres were obtained by the sol-gel method. In particular, the nitrogen-rich carbon spheres were prepd. by 1-pot hydrothermal synthesis in the presence of resorcinol/formaldehyde as carbon precursors and ethylenediamine (EDA) as both a base catalyst and nitrogen precursor, followed by carbonization in nitrogen and activation with CO2. The introduction of EDA to the sol-gel system resulted in structurally bonded nitrogen-contg. carbon spheres. The nitrogen doping level and the particle size can be tuned by varying the EDA amt. in the reaction mixt. The max. nitrogen doping level of 7.2% in carbon spheres could be achieved without sacrificing the spherical morphol. The diam. of these carbon spheres (CS) can be tuned in the rage of 50-1200 nm by varying the EDA amt. N2 adsorption anal. showed that the aforementioned activated carbon spheres exhibited high surface area reaching up to 1224 m2/g. Ultra high CO2 adsorption capacities, 4.1 and 6.2 mmol/g, corresponding to an equil. pressure of 1 bar, were measured on nitrogen-contg. activated carbon spheres at 25 and 0Â°, resp. Electrochem. measurements performed on these carbon spheres for double layer capacitors showed very high capacitance up to â¼388 F/g at 1.0 A/g, outstanding rate capability (60% capacitance retention at 100 A/g), and unprecedented cycling stability (â¼98% capacitance retention even after 8000 cycles) in 1 M H2SO4 electrolyte soln.

Exceptional gas adsorption properties by nitrogen-doped porous carbons derived from benzimidazole-linked polymers
Ashourirad, Babak; Sekizkardes, Ali Kemal; Altarawneh, Suha; El-Kaderi, Hani M.

Heteroatom-doped porous carbons are emerging as platforms for use in a wide range of applications including catalysis, energy storage, and gas sepn. or storage, among others. The use of high activation temps. and heteroatom multiple-source precursors remain great challenges, and this study aims to addresses both issues. A series of highly porous N-doped carbon (CPC) materials was successfully synthesized by chem. activation of benzimidazole-linked polymers (BILPs) followed by thermolysis under argon. The high temp. synthesized CPC-700 reaches surface area and pore vol. as high as 3240 m2 g-1 and 1.51 cm3 g-1, resp., while low temp. activated CPC-550 exhibits the highest ultramicropore vol. of 0.35 cm3 g-1. The controlled activation process endows CPCs with diverse textural properties, adjustable nitrogen content (1-8 wt %), and remarkable gas sorption properties. In particular, exceptionally high CO2 uptake capacities of 5.8 mmol g-1 (1.0 bar) and 2.1 mmol g-1 (0.15 bar) at ambient temp. were obtained for materials prepd. at 550 Â°C due to a combination of a high level of N-doping and ultramicroporosity. Furthermore, CPCs prepd. at higher temps. exhibit remarkable total uptake for CO2 (25.7 mmol g-1 at 298 K and 30 bar) and CH4 (20.5 mmol g-1 at 298 K and 65 bar) as a result of higher total micropores and small mesopores vol. Interestingly, the N sites within the imidazole rings of BILPs are intrinsically located in pyrrolic/pyridinic positions typically found in N-doped carbons. Therefore, the chem. and phys. transformation of BILPs into CPCs is thermodynamically favored and saves significant amts. of energy that would otherwise be consumed during carbonization processes.

Highly porous N-doped carbons have been successfully prepd. by using KOH as activating agent and polypyrrole (PPy) as carbon precursor. These materials were investigated as sorbents for CO2 capture. The activation process was carried out under severe (KOH/PPy = 4) or mild (KOH/PPy = 2) activation conditions at different temps. in the 600-800 Â°C range. Mildly activated carbons have two important characteristics: (i) they contain a large no. of nitrogen functional groups (up to 10.1 wt% N) identified as pyridonic-N with a small proportion of pyridinic-N groups, and (ii) they exhibit, in relation to the carbons prepd. with KOH/PPy = 4, narrower micropore sizes. The combination of both of these properties explains the large CO2 adsorption capacities of mildly activated carbon. In particular, a very high CO2 adsorption uptake of 6.2 mmolÂ·g-1 (0 Â°C) was achieved for porous carbons prepd. with KOH/PPy = 2 and 600 Â°C (1700 m2Â·g-1, pore size â 1 nm and 10.1 wt% N). Furthermore, we obsd. that these porous carbons exhibit high CO2 adsorption rates, a good selectivity for CO2-N2 sepn. and it can be easily regenerated.

Significantly Increased CO2 Adsorption Performance of Nanostructured Templated Carbon by Tuning Surface Area and Nitrogen Doping
Wang, Lifeng; Yang, Ralph T.

Carbon dioxide adsorption properties of a series of templated carbon adsorbents with high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface areas (1361-3840 m2/g) and with/without nitrogen doping (6-7 wt % N) were systematically studied. Two linear relationships between CO2 adsorption capacities and surface areas of nitrogen-doped/undoped nanostructured templated carbons were first established. The doped nitrogen was present in the forms of pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrolic/pyridonic nitrogen, quaternary nitrogen, and an oxidized form of nitrogen. The interaction energies with CO2, as approximated by the isosteric heats of adsorption, were increased from 30 kJ/mol on the undoped carbon to 50 kJ/mol on the N-doped carbon as a result of these nitrogen sites. The increased interactions led to an enhancement in CO2 adsorption capacity by a factor of 2, while N2 uptake was not enhanced. The optimized N-doped templated carbon, N-TC-EMC, possessed remarkable CO2 capacity (4 mmol/g at 1 atm and 298 K) and selectivity (CO2/N2 at 1 atm = 14). Postdoping ammonia treatment was found beneficial to CO2 adsorption. CO2 performance of N-doped carbon under wet condition and conditions relevant to flue gas, rates of adsorption, and regeneration requirement, which are important for practical applications, were also investigated. The results showed that N-doped templated carbon exhibited all prerequisite attributes for CO2 capture and storage applications: high CO2 capacity and CO2/N2 selectivity, fast and reversible adsorption, thermal and moisture stabilities, and ease in CO2 desorption.

Nitrogen-Doped Carbon Nanotube Arrays with High Electrocatalytic Activity for Oxygen Reduction
Gong, Kuanping; Du, Feng; Xia, Zhenhai; Durstock, Michael; Dai, Liming

The large-scale practical application of fuel cells will be difficult to realize if the expensive platinum-based electrocatalysts for oxygen redn. reactions (ORRs) cannot be replaced by other efficient, low-cost, and stable electrodes. Here, we report that vertically aligned nitrogen-contg. carbon nanotubes (VA-NCNTs) can act as a metal-free electrode with a much better electrocatalytic activity, long-term operation stability, and tolerance to crossover effect than platinum for oxygen redn. in alk. fuel cells. In air-satd. 0.1 M potassium hydroxide, we obsd. a steady-state output potential of -80 mV and a c.d. of 4.1 milliamps per square centimeter at -0.22 V, compared with -85 mV and 1.1 milliamps per square centimeter at -0.20 V for a platinum-carbon electrode. The incorporation of electron-accepting nitrogen atoms in the conjugated nanotube carbon plane appears to impart a relatively high pos. charge d. on adjacent carbon atoms. This effect, coupled with aligning the NCNTs, provides a four-electron pathway for the ORR on VA-NCNTs with a superb performance.

Mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbon materials with high surface areas up to 1500 m2 g-1 were conveniently made by the carbonization of nucleobases dissolved in an all-org. ionic liq. (1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium dicyanamide). Using hard templating with silica nanoparticles, this process yields high-surface-area nitrogen-doped carbon materials with nitrogen contents as high as 12 wt %, narrow mesopore size distribution of ca. 12 nm diam., and local graphitic carbon structure. It is demonstrated that the resulting nitrogen-doped carbons show very high catalytic activity, even in the metal-free case in the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) for fuel cells. Specifically, the as-prepd. materials exhibit a low onset voltage for ORR in alk. medium and a high methanol tolerance, compared with those of com. 20 wt % Pt/C catalyst. We regard this as a first step toward an all-sustainable fuel cell, avoiding noble metals.

Developing non-precious metal electrocatalysts (NPMCs) for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) is of paramount importance for com. implementation of several clean energy techniques (e.g. proton exchange membrane fuel cells). However, limited understanding of the ORR catalytic mechanism of NPMCs greatly hinders the progress in the precise fabrication of NPMCs at the mol. or at. level. Recently, an increasing no. of studies have demonstrated the crucial role of a carbon matrix in exposing, stabilizing, and activating the catalytic sites, thus providing a platform to identify the nature of NPMCs. Herein, the unique structural effects of a carbon matrix in NPMCs are first reviewed to inspire the development of more advanced NPMCs for the ORR.

Developing highly efficient catalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) is key to the fabrication of com. viable fuel cell devices and metal-air batteries for future energy applications. Herein, we review the most recent advances in the development of Pt-based and Pt-free materials in the field of fuel cell ORR catalysis. This review covers catalyst material selection, design, synthesis, and characterization, as well as the theor. understanding of the catalysis process and mechanisms. The integration of these catalysts into fuel cell operations and the resulting performance/durability are also discussed. Finally, we provide insights into the remaining challenges and directions for future perspectives and research.

A novel strategy for efficient growth of nitrogen-doped graphene (N-graphene) on a large scale from s-triazine molecules is presented. The growth process has been unveiled in situ using time-dependent photoemission. It has been established that a postannealing of N-graphene after gold intercalation causes a conversion of the N environment from pyridinic to graphitic, allowing to obtain more than 80% of all embedded nitrogen in graphitic form, which is essential for the electron doping in graphene. A band gap, a doping level of 300 meV, and a charge-carrier concentration of â¼8Ã10(12) electrons per cm2, induced by 0.4 atom % of graphitic nitrogen, have been detected by angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, which offers great promise for implementation of this system in next generation electronic devices.

The microporous structure of Fe-N-doped carbon (Fe-N-C) catalysts plays a pivotal role in the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) because the catalytically active N-coordinated Fe ion sites are located within accessible micropores (<2 nm). However, the distinct role of carbon support microporosity in the formation of catalytic sites in Fe-N-C catalysts remains unclear. Here, we report the effect of the pre-defined microporosity of the parent carbon support on the catalytic site d. resulting from Fe-N-C catalyst synthesis, and its ultimate effect on ORR activity. The porosity, pore size distribution, and sp. surface area of the carbon supports are initially controlled by using hot CO2 treatment. Then, Fe and N are doped into these supports by precursor impregnation and subsequent pyrolysis. In the synthesized Fe-N-C catalysts, the more developed microporosity in the parent carbon supports facilitates more iron and nitrogen contents, esp. pyridinic nitrogen, and Fe-N-Cs derived from carbon supports with higher microporosities show enhanced ORR activity, strongly suggesting that a high catalytic site d. can be achieved by utilizing carbon supports with well-developed microporosities. The most active Fe-N-C catalyst prepd. using our synthetic route exhibits ORR activity comparable to that of a com. Pt-based catalyst in alk. media.
